title: How to Check for Head Lice at Home (Without Panic)
description: A practical, parent-friendly checklist for spotting lice and nits quickly and calmly.
author: Head Lice Checker Editorial Team
body: Head lice are common and manageable, but uncertainty can escalate quickly when a child starts itching. A calm, structured check gives better answers than a rushed look under poor lighting.
Start with bright light and a fine-tooth comb. Part hair in narrow sections so you can inspect near the scalp rather than only scanning the surface.
Check behind both ears and the nape first. These zones are often where indicators appear earliest and where missed signs can delay confirmation.
Look for attached oval particles on one side of the hair shaft. Loose flakes that brush away easily are more often dandruff or dry scalp debris.
Use tissue contrast during comb passes. Wipe the comb after each section and compare what you see across multiple areas rather than relying on one strand.
If your first check is unclear, capture two or three close-up photos and run an indicative scan to prioritize urgency. Better photos improve confidence.
When likely indicators repeat across sections or household symptoms overlap, move to professional confirmation quickly. Early action usually reduces household spread.
Remember the boundary: this is practical guidance, not diagnosis. If symptoms persist or worsen, seek clinician support.

title: Nits vs Dandruff: Key Differences Parents Miss
description: Learn the visual differences between fixed nits and loose scalp flakes.
author: Head Lice Checker Clinical Review
body: Nits and dandruff are often confused, especially in rushed checks at the end of the day. The distinction matters because next steps are very different.
Nits are usually oval and fixed to one side of the hair shaft. They remain attached when hair is gently moved or blown.
Dandruff appears as irregular loose flakes and usually dislodges with light brushing. It can appear across surface hair and on clothing.
The movement test is useful but should not be your only test. Always check multiple sections in bright light before deciding.
Product residue can create false alarms. Dry shampoo buildup or styling product fragments may look similar under weak lighting.
Pattern matters more than one isolated speck. Repeated attached ovals near scalp zones increase the likelihood that you should escalate.
If image quality is poor, recapture before acting. A sharper close-up often resolves uncertainty quickly.
When ambiguity remains, seek professional confirmation instead of repeating uncertain home checks.

title: School Outbreak Response: A Practical 48-Hour Playbook
description: A communication and screening flow schools can use to reduce disruption and stigma.
author: Head Lice Checker Education Team
body: When reports rise, schools need a calm framework that reduces panic and keeps parent messaging consistent. The first 48 hours set the tone.
Start with a neutral notice: explain that concerns are manageable, provide home-check steps, and avoid singling out children.
Encourage same-week household checks with clear instructions on lighting, sectioning, and where to look first.
Provide scan-first guidance for uncertain households. Indicative triage can help families decide whether to monitor or book confirmation quickly.
Avoid stigma-heavy policies. Focus communication on practical routine checks and respectful language across all channels.
By day two, issue a short reminder with the same core instructions and escalation triggers for persistent symptoms.
For families still unsure, direct them to professional clinics for confirmation rather than repeated uncertain treatments.
Review outcomes after each cluster: what language worked, where confusion appeared, and how to improve the next response cycle.
